column2: Hooks under .git/hooks can be used to do lots of things, like running a code formatter before committing, or executing arbitrary code.
column3: Not bad! You must be a little bit paranoid and at the same time know a lot about git ğŸ˜œ

column2: `git diff --staged` shows the changes that would be included if you run `git commit` right now.
column3: The stage is yours! ğŸ¤

column2: `git commit` creates a new 'save point' including the changes mentioned in `git diff --staged`.
column3: Creating a check point... ğŸ§¾

column2: `git commit -am 'My second feature'` commits all unstaged changes with a short message
column3: HDGDL ğŸ“²

column2: `git diff` shows the unstaged changes, so the ones you currently would not include in the next commit.
column3: Small things can make the _diff_erence ğŸ”¬

column2: `git diff <COMMIT/BRANCH NAME>` shows the diff compared to that commit. For 'diff' you can always add `-- some/path` to limit the diff.
column3: Big or small differences ğŸ’¯

column2: `git add <file>` stages a file for a following commit
column3: Do you want to add me to your friendlist? â•

column2: `git switch <BRANCH NAME>` allows you to switch to a specific branch.
column3: Please dont switch off! ğŸ”Œ

column2: `git show <COMMIT HASH>` shows you the changes of a specific commit.
column3: Show me what else you can do! ğŸ¤“

column2: `git switch -c <NEW BRANCH NAME>` creates a new branch.
column3: Can't see the tree for all the branches... ğŸŒ³

column2: `git log <COMMIT HASH>` shows the commit history of the current commit.
column3: Don't we all have a long history?! ğŸ›ï¸

column2: `git tag -a <TAG NAME> -m 'My annotation'` will create an annotated tag.
column3: Let's play tag! ğŸ·ï¸

column2: You can use git as a data base to store arbitrary things in. If that is a good idea is a different question...
column3: Didn't I explicitly tell you not to look there? ğŸ˜¸

column2: `git rebase <COMMIT/BRANCH NAME>` will pretend you did your commits based on the referenced commit/branch to achieve a clean history.
column3: Doesn't cleaning up feel good? ğŸ§¹

column2: `git rebase -i <COMMIT/BRANCH NAME>` will allow you to reorder commits or modify them
column3: Let's pretend the past didn't happen! ğŸ›ï¸

column2: `git cherry-pick <COMMIT>` allows to get the changes from a single commit of a different branch into yours.
column3: I like cherries! ğŸ’

column2: `git push` uploads the commits from your current branch to the server.
column3: Uploading your mind... ğŸ†™

column2: `git pull` downloads the latest commits from the server and will apply them to the branch you are currently on.
column3: Don't feel down for downloading things... You are doing great! ğŸ“ˆ

column2: `git reset --hard <COMMIT/BRANCH>` will remove all your changes and point the current branch to the new commit
column3: When things donâ€™t go as planned, just hit the reset button on your hopes! ğŸ”™

column2: `git reset --soft <COMMIT/BRANCH>` keeps your changes, but removes commits from the history (or depending on what you call it with it can actually add them, tooâ€¦)
